sub_topic: Using the Fourier transform to solve boundary value problems
message_1:
A metal rod of length 4 cm has a temperature distribution given by 

T(x) = 10 sin(πx/4) - 5 cos(3πx/4) + 2

where x is the distance measured from one end of the rod. 

Find the temperature at the center of the rod.
message_2:
To find the temperature at the center of the rod, we need to find the value of T(x) when x is half the length of the rod, which is 2 cm. So, we will substitute x = 2 in the given equation:

T(2) = 10 sin(π(2)/4) - 5 cos(3π(2)/4) + 2

T(2) = 10 sin(π/2) - 5 cos(3π/2) + 2

Now, we know that sin(π/2) = 1 and cos(3π/2) = 0. Therefore,

T(2) = 10(1) - 5(0) + 2

T(2) = 10 + 2

T(2) = 12

So, the temperature at the center of the rod is 12°C.
